author: By Emma Goldberg
title: With Inflation, Workers Are Facing Return-to-Office Sticker Shock
description: The cost of a daily routine — travel, coffee, food — is far pricier than it was when offices shut down two years ago.
content: As the security software company KnowBe4 weighed whether to require a return to the office, executives knew to anticipate a certain set of concerns from employees. Less flexibility. More time in transit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: An Ace Took the Harder Option. Bad News for the Giants.
description: The Mets won both games of a doubleheader against San Francisco, and Max Scherzer’s decision to pitch the second game was all about teamwork.
content: The easy choice, for Max Scherzer, would have been to start the first game of Tuesday’s doubleheader at Citi Field. Pitchers thrive on routine, and only the opening game had a scheduled time for the first pitch. Scherzer has a Hall of Fame résumé, and if he had insisted on the opener for his first home start as a Met, he could have had his way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Steinhauer
title: Protest and Pleasure: Riffs on Classical Indian Art
description: Devotion meets consciousness-raising in the first museum survey of the artist-activist Jaishri Abichandani at Craft Contemporary in Los Angeles.
content: LOS ANGELES — Some of Jaishri Abichandani’s artworks are so palpable, they evoke a strong sense of touch just by looking at them. The centerpieces of “Flower-Headed Children,” her solo exhibition at Craft Contemporary, are figures sculpted from polymer clay and decked in petals and jewelry. They appear handmade, with an attention to detail that seems as pleasureful as it is painstaking. Filled with color — including walls painted blue and gold — and traditionally beautiful materials, the show revels in visual abundance. It reminds you, in case you’ve forgotten amid an endless stream of Zoom meetings, of the delights of physicality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: How The Times Has Mapped the War in Ukraine
description: Graphics journalists use annotated maps to show readers the current state of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
content: Maps have played a critical role in The New York Times’s coverage of the war in Ukraine — and nearly every graphics journalist at the organization, from New York to Seoul to London, has helped with the mapping effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Why ‘Border Control’ Politics Is More About Control Than Borders
description: A quirk of political psychology helps explain the British government’s plan to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda.
content: Sometimes I choose a newsletter topic because it’s in the headlines. Sometimes it’s to point out a phenomenon that is shaping politics around the world, in ways that often go unnoticed, and to explain how to recognize its fingerprints on news events that recur reliably month after month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Scientists Find No Benefit to Time-Restricted Eating
description: In a yearlong study, participants who confined meals to certain hours lost no more weight than those who ate at any time.
content: The weight-loss idea is quite appealing: Limit your eating to a period of six to eight hours each day, during which you can have whatever you want.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russia’s offensive in eastern Ukraine.
content: Russia plunged into a new, more methodical chapter of the war in Ukraine yesterday, intent on crushing Ukrainian defenses while avoiding the same blunders that badly damaged Russian forces in the conflict’s first weeks. Russian officials said missile and artillery forces had struck hundreds of Ukrainian military targets overnight. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Mauk
title: Building the First Long-Distance Hiking Trail in Kurdistan
description: Can it help knit together a nation?
content: Lawin Mohammad collects trails in the mountains of Kurdistan. He has met scores of shepherds on their daily wanderings. He confers with beekeepers on high passes. He follows aging pesh merga on their former patrols and waylays Christian and Yazidi pilgrims. When he is stopped on the highway at a military checkpoint, staring into the aviators of a heavily armed 20-year-old, he will ask the soldier whether he ever walks to the next village over. Or if his grandfather ever did. He makes inquiries among Syrians like himself who a decade ago took the dangerous crossing from Rojava into the foothills of the Zagros Mountains, in northern Iraq, at the start of the civil war. He parleys with children and imams. I have seen him work over at least one furtive treasure hunter. His informants are legion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia says it has successfully tested a new intercontinental missile that can evade defenses.
description: Though officials said the missile is not yet ready to deploy, President Vladimir V. Putin said the launch of the Sarmat missile “will force all who are trying to threaten our country in the heat of frenzied, aggressive rhetoric to think twice.”
content: Russia announced on Wednesday it had successfully launched a new missile that it said could deploy nuclear warheads at hypersonic speeds anywhere in the world and outwit defenses, a move that President Vladimir V. Putin said was aimed at showing Russia’s adversaries that they needed to “think twice” before threatening his country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, 95, Dies; Fought for Mexico’s ‘Disappeared’
description: When her son vanished in 1975, she began a crusade on behalf of him and hundreds of others and became a voice of moral authority on the left.
content: When Rosario Ibarra de Piedra’s 21-year-old son was arrested at an antigovernment rally in Mexico in 1975, he disappeared for good. She spent most of her life searching for him — and while her search was unsuccessful, it led to a political career, and to her eventual emergence as the defiant figurehead of Mexico’s embattled left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla’s profits jumped in the first quarter, but challenges loom.
description: The electric carmaker had to close an important factory in Shanghai because of China’s efforts to stamp out a coronavirus outbreak.
content: Tesla said on Wednesday that it made a $3.3 billion profit in the first three months of the year, up from $438 million a year earlier and the biggest quarterly profit since the company’s creation. But Tesla also said it expected its factories to run below capacity for the rest of 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Lynn
title: West Orange, N.J.: Plentiful Green Space and an Easy Commute
description: During the pandemic, the Essex County township has attracted city buyers with its open space and relatively affordable housing — all less than 20 miles from Midtown.
content: Living in a Brooklyn apartment with two young children in the middle of the pandemic, Megan Melamed, 41, and Alex Abell, 39, started their search for a suburban home in Maplewood, N.J. But the couple, both social workers, soon realized it was out of their price range, so they turned to the nearby Essex County township of West Orange, where they eventually bought a 1915 house with four bedrooms in October 2020, for $457,500.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: United Airlines foresees record revenues after a big quarterly loss.
description: The carrier’s chief predicted a “historic inflection point for our business,” with strong demand despite fare increases fed by rising fuel prices.
content: United Airlines, while announcing a big first-quarter loss, said Wednesday that it expected record revenue in the coming months, suggesting it had reached a pandemic turning point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar faces a health emergency as its military regime targets doctors.
description: In recent weeks, Myanmar’s security forces have intensified their crackdown on doctors who oppose the military junta that seized power 14 months ago. Doctors have been at the forefront of a nationwide civil disobedience movement that has crippled the economy, and the regime has targeted health care workers from the start.
content: In recent weeks, Myanmar’s security forces have intensified their crackdown on doctors who oppose the military junta that seized power 14 months ago. Doctors have been at the forefront of a nationwide civil disobedience movement that has crippled the economy, and the regime has targeted health care workers from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Giovannini
title: She’s the Peggy Guggenheim of SoHo
description: Steward of a collection of 20th century art, Laura Mattioli made a future for the Futurists at the Center for Italian Modern Art in Manhattan.
content: Think of her as Peggy Guggenheim in reverse. Laura Mattioli Rossi: an Italian, not an American, living in New York, not Venice, near Canal Street, not the Grand Canal. She established and runs a private foundation in New York, the Center for Italian Modern Art (CIMA), which recalls the private, one-woman Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Tours Argue Wimbledon Sets ‘Damaging Precedent’ in Barring Russian and Belarusian Players
description: The men’s and women’s tours disagreed with the major tournament’s move to exclude individual athletes from those countries from competition in the aftermath of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: Professional tennis, which had been unusually united of late, is back in disaccord after Wimbledon’s bold and difficult decision to bar Russian and Belarusian players from this year’s tournament was met with strong disapproval by the men’s and women’s tours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: White Connecticut Trooper Charged in Killing of Black Man During Stolen Car Chase
description: Trooper Brian D. North was charged with manslaughter in the fatal shooting of Mubarak Soulemane, 19, in January, 2020.
content: A Connecticut state trooper who fatally shot a 19-year-old Black man after a car chase two years ago has been charged with manslaughter, state investigators said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: New Jersey Diocese Agrees to Settle Sex Abuse Claims for $87.5 Million
description: The settlement with the Camden diocese is among the largest such agreements involving the Catholic Church in the United States.
content: The Diocese of Camden, N.J., said on Tuesday that it had agreed to pay $87.5 million to settle claims made by hundreds of people who accused clergy members of sexually abusing them, one of the largest such settlements involving the Catholic Church in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Justice Dept. Appeals to Reinstate Transportation Mask Mandate
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ruled the mandate “necessary,” but an appeal risks creating a precedent that could permanently constrain the agency.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Wednesday appealed a federal court ruling striking down the mask requirement for passengers on planes, trains, buses and other public transportation after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention concluded that the mandate was “necessary” to protect the public from the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross, David F. Gallagher and Anna Schaverien
title: The End of Mask Mandates
description: As major airlines and some public transit operators drop requirements to wear face coverings, further conflicts may be on the horizon.
content: Major U.S. airlines have lifted mask mandates after a federal judge ruled that face coverings would no longer be required on airplanes, trains and other public transportation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Randall
title: Football Tech That’s More Than a Laser and Light Show
description: The U.S.F.L. is testing tech that could resolve disputes over where balls are spotted, clearly show if a first down was reached and track players who stand too high on tackles. The N.F.L. is watching.
content: The new United States Football League, which debuted last weekend, is betting that fans want more pro football in the lull before the N.F.L. season begins. To win that bet, the league is experimenting with technology to make games move quickly, make officiating as accurate as possible, improve player performance and safety tracking and enhance the TV broadcast for fans (Fox is an investor in the league).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: 6 Rohingya Refugees Are Killed Fleeing Detention Center in Malaysia
description: In recent years, the Malaysian government has taken a more hard-line approach to the refugees in the country, which once offered a modicum of opportunity.
content: As hundreds of Rohingya refugees fled a detention center in Malaysia, six of them, including two children, were killed on Wednesday when they were struck by a car crossing a highway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Michael Levenson
title: Ohio Doctor Is Acquitted of Killing Patients With Fentanyl
description: The doctor, William Husel, had faced 14 counts of murder after his patients overdosed on fentanyl, the powerful opioid.
content: An Ohio doctor who had been accused of killing 14 patients with overdoses of fentanyl from 2014 to 2018 was acquitted on Wednesday by a county jury, bringing an end to one of the state’s largest murder cases, which set off a debate about end-of-life medical care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: 4 Who Helped Catch Shooting Suspect Get a Grateful City’s Thanks
description: The mayor and police commissioner honored the tipsters who alerted the police after seeing Frank R. James, who was then arrested in the Brooklyn subway shooting.
content: Before they helped catch a man accused of carrying out the worst attack on the New York City subway in decades, before the police commissioner said they were heroes and before they were given a reward for their quick actions, Mohamad Cheikh and Zack Tahhan had just been two guys spending a regular day at work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Parking Shuffle Returns; Drivers Honk in Dismay
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April, 20, 2022.
content: “It’s another way to make residents’ lives impossible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Mary Weatherford Brings ‘Horror and Beauty’ to Venice
description: Inspired by Titian’s “The Flaying of Marsyas,” the midcareer artist is showing a series of shadowy and somber works at Museo di Palazzo Grimani.
content: VENICE — It is the kind of horrific painting that makes you want to look away: Titian’s “The Flaying of Marsyas” depicts a satyr — half man, half goat — hanging upside down as he is skinned alive, while a dog laps up his blood and a musician impassively plays the violin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Can Ukraine Keep Winning?
description: As a new phase of the war begins, we look at Russia’s advantages — and Ukraine’s.
content: Ukraine has defeated Russia in the first phase of their war, and a second phase has begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: Why Those Moments of Care for Liza Minnelli and Joni Mitchell Felt Different
description: Awards shows are a natural setting for honoring aging legends. It’s reassuring when they don’t try to hide the frailty that aging can bring.
content: The first 53 minutes of music’s biggest night rolled along smoothly. This year’s Grammys had centerpiece performances from Olivia Rodrigo and BTS, plus a big reception for the newly minted Oscar winner Questlove; Trevor Noah, the host, told jokes that offended nobody’s spouse. It was only after Rodrigo accepted the award for Best New Artist that something unexpected happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wyna Liu
title: The Russian Doll Puzzle
description: Wyna Liu, a New York Times Crossword editor, examines a nontraditional crossword puzzle.
content: Welcome to The Lab, a new series that examines a nontraditional puzzle that pushes the boundaries of puzzle making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Radu Lupu, Pianist Who Awed Listeners, Is Dead at 76
description: Preferring the stage (and an office chair) to the recording studio, he enthralled audiences with ruminative performances that evoked the otherworldly.
content: Radu Lupu, a pianist of rare refinement whose ruminative, enigmatic performances and recordings wove spells over his listeners, induced awe among his colleagues and confirmed him as one of the finest musicians ever to have graced his instrument, died on Sunday at his home in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Aid groups fight to deliver lifesaving supplies despite losing lives to Russian shelling.
description: Only one member of an aid convoy to Chernihiv, Ukraine, survived a shelling attack in March. But the convoy’s organizers have persisted through the dangers of the war.
content: On a bracingly cold day in March, four people set out from Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, to deliver lifesaving medicines, heating devices and food to the besieged residents of Chernihiv, in the northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: A German software giant is unplugging its Russia business.
description: As SAP takes steps to wind down its cloud services in Russia, Continental said it was required to “temporarily” restart a Russian tire factory.
content: In the days after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the German software giant SAP halted all its sales in Russia. But it provoked the ire of Ukrainian leaders by continuing to offer updates and cloud computing access to Russian customers not targeted by Western sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: A Ukrainian Town Goes Underground as Russia Assaults the East.
description: As Ukrainian forces dig into trenches and residents flee into basements, Russia’s artillery attacks have intensified. “They can’t get through the front lines and so they’re starting simply to destroy the city,” a Ukrainian official said.
content: AVDIIVKA, Ukraine — Spartak Kyurdzhiev was bragging to friends on Wednesday that he never hides from bombings anymore when a volley of rocket fire landed with such intensity nearby that he dashed into the school he was standing in front of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The Treasury Department takes action to crack down on Russian sanctions evasion.
description: New sanctions target a Russian bank and cryptocurrency mining company.
content: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department on Wednesday moved to crack down on Russia’s efforts to evade sanctions by imposing a new set of measures targeting a Russian bank, a cryptocurrency mining company and a network of individuals who are accused of facilitating illicit transactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Cypress Hill: Insane in the Brain’ Review: Influential Rappers, Still Smokin’
description: This documentary by Estevan Oriol chronicles the rise of a group that he has been around since its inception.
content: In 1991, just a few years after Public Enemy released the single “Bring the Noise,” Cypress Hill, a hip-hop trio out of South Gate, near Los Angeles, released a debut that followed that exhortation to astonishing effect. The rapper B-Real delivered his anti-cop, pro-weed rhymes in a taunting, nasal tone, countered by the abrupt barks of Sen Dog. DJ Muggs created beats that were inventively off-kilter and put high-pitched whistles and sirens under and around hooks that were more than earworms — these tracks got under your whole skin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: The Justice Department charged 21 people over coronavirus-related fraud schemes.
description: The schemes included selling fake vaccination cards and test results, as well as enticing patients to accept unneeded treatments, tests and telehealth visits.
content: The Justice Department has accused two owners of a medical lab in Southern California of running a $144 million Medicare fraud scheme that billed thousands of patients for unnecessary medical diagnostics — after luring them in with coronavirus tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Forman Jr. and Kayla Vinson
title: The Superpredator Myth Did a Lot of Damage. Courts Are Beginning to See the Light.
description: We don’t need to keep everyone in prison forever.
content: Over the past decade, many Americans have come to agree that we lock up too many people, for too long, in miserable conditions. But despite a growing political movement against prisons, imprisonment rates remain stubbornly high, and the United States is still the world leader in incarceration. To meaningfully shrink the prison system will require states to do something few have wanted to do: reduce some of the extremely long sentences imposed in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Prince Harry Puts Noses Out of Joint With Comments About the Queen
description: The prince, in Europe for the Invictus Games, visited his grandmother then told the “Today” show that he wanted to make sure “she’s protected.”
content: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II turns 96 on Thursday, a milestone she will mark out of sight at her country estate, Sandringham. But the birthday has not arrived without a dollop of drama from her self-exiled grandson, Prince Harry, who said this week he wanted to make sure the aging queen was “protected.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Why Is Gut Health Taking Over TikTok?
description: Despite what social media might have you believe, there is no overnight shortcut to better digestive health.
content: Every few months, like clockwork, hundreds of videos promising tips and tricks to “hack” your gut flood TikTok. In March, influencers pushed shots of aloe vera juice: “My digestive system, like my gut health? Never been better,” one gushed in a video with one million likes while tapping on a purple bottle of the drink. Another, with the username “oliveoilqueen,” advocated drinking extra virgin olive oil every day in a video viewed more than 3.5 million times, claiming that doing so cleared her skin, made her periods less painful and fixed her frequent bloating. Videos tagged with #guttok have garnered nearly 400 million views. They’re crammed with suggestions for cucumber-ginger juices and boiled apples, bone broth in the morning and sludgy sweet potato soups at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Debates Whether Miranda Warnings Are a Constitutional Right
description: The justices considered whether a California hospital attendant could sue a police officer who questioned him without reading him his rights.
content: WASHINGTON — If there is one constitutional protection known to anyone with a television set, it is the familiar warning required by the Supreme Court’s 1966 decision in Miranda v. Arizona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: multitude
description: This word has appeared in 153 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word multitude has appeared in 153 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 4 in “Meteor Showers That Will Peak in Night Skies in 2022” by Adam Mann:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Three Ways to Cut Your Tech Spending, as Prices Rise Everywhere
description: Here’s how to be mindful about the tech subscriptions, phone bills and upgrades that drain our budgets.
content: With the cost of food, gas and electricity going up, we have no choice but to spend more. But we do have more control over how many dollars we allocate to one of our largest-ticket items: personal technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Neither Party Is Happy About Biden’s Handling of the Border
description: How much of the blame does he deserve, and how much more can he do?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: An Interrupted Conversation: The Flamenco Festival Returns
description: Despite an impressive roster, including Manuel Liñán’s “Viva!,” this year’s edition, the 20th, represents a radically streamlined version of the festival.
content: Flamenco is like an animated conversation. Singers, guitarists and dancers face off, bodies listening, instruments generating and responding to movement. At the end of an evening, the performers often move across the stage in a tight cluster, as if meaning to continue the discussion offstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Inquiry Finds ‘Systemic Failures’ at Mississippi Prison
description: A report singled out solitary confinement and enforced segregation as particularly harmful practices that contributed to the poor mental and physical health of prisoners.
content: WASHINGTON — Officials at Mississippi’s largest prison routinely violated the rights of prisoners by failing to provide mental health treatment, suicide counseling and protection from violence, among its “systemic failures” that led to widespread death and despair, the Justice Department said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: A Coveted Recipe From Jamaica Is Finally Shared
description: This is fish rubbed with garlic and allspice, shallow-fried until the skin crisps, then doused with hot vinegar, carrots, onions and wicked Scotch bonnets.
content: ‘‘Francine is coming,’’ they say. And then, leaning in, ‘‘She’s making escovitch.’’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Arizona Wildfires Seize on Chaotic Winds and Parched Forests
description: An uncontained springtime blaze north of Flagstaff, along with smaller fires in New Mexico and Colorado, has been a harsh reminder that fire season might now be year-round.
content: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. — In a gas station parking lot crowded with firefighters and anxious evacuees on Wednesday, a woman sat in her car and cried while watching wildfire smoke spew across her neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Dede Robertson, Wife and Partner of Pat Robertson, Dies at 94
description: A founding board member of the Christian Broadcasting Network, she also campaigned for her husband when he ran for president in 1988.
content: Dede Robertson, the wife of the religious broadcaster Pat Robertson and a founding board member of his Christian Broadcasting Network, died on Tuesday at her home in Virginia Beach. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Ezra Miller, ‘The Flash’ Actor, Arrested on Assault Charge in Hawaii
description: The ‘Fantastic Beasts’ star was accused of throwing a chair after being asked to leave a home, causing a woman’s injury.
content: Ezra Miller, who has played the superhero The Flash in several movies and television series, is facing an assault charge in Hawaii after being accused of hurling a chair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: The Limón Dance Company Navigates the Present
description: The company, belatedly celebrating its 75th anniversary, presented a program with works by Limón and Doris Humphrey and a premiere by Olivier Tarpaga.
content: José Limón died in 1972. The Limón Dance Company, which he founded in 1946, lives on. On Tuesday, it returned to the Joyce Theater for a two-week run, a pandemic-delayed 75th anniversary celebration, under the new directorship of Dante Puleio. The first program (a second follows next week) accomplished the essential tasks: displaying a company in good shape, honoring the past without getting stuck in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas F. Madden
title: Looking for Europe’s Future in an Overlooked Corner of the Continent
description: Robert D. Kaplan’s “Adriatic” takes readers on a political, intellectual and personal tour from Italy to Albania.
content: One can learn much from this idiosyncratic book, although only a little about the Adriatic. As Robert D. Kaplan, the author of several books on international affairs, tells it, “Adriatic” is “not military strategy, political science, original archival history, conventional long-form journalism, traditional travel writing, memoir or literary criticism. After all, what does the poetry of Ezra Pound have to do with the current position of the West and Russia in Montenegro?” A good question — although one left unanswered. Instead, Kaplan offers the reader a diverse collection of observations, ruminations, narrations and occasional incriminations clustered around a travelogue through cities on or near the eponymous sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy and Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Where Do Travelers Need to Wear Masks Now?
description: After a federal mask mandate was struck down on Monday, travelers are facing a patchwork of rules spanning air travel, trains, buses, cruise ships and ride-hailing services. Here’s what to know.
content: A federal judge in Florida struck down the federal mask requirement for planes and public transit on Monday, which had been set to expire on May 3. Within 24 hours, all major U.S. airlines, as well as the Amtrak rail system, had declared that they were no longer requiring masks for passengers or employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: A YouTuber Purposely Crashed His Plane in California, F.A.A. Says
description: The video from December shows Trevor Jacob cursing in panic before leaping with a parachute out of a small plane. Some experts had wondered if the crash was a publicity stunt.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration has found that Trevor Jacob, a daredevil YouTuber who posted a video of himself last year parachuting out of a plane that he claimed had malfunctioned, purposely abandoned the aircraft and allowed it to crash into the Los Padres National Forest in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Nicolas Cage Is in on the Nicolas Cage Jokes
description: In his new movie, “The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent,” the actor plays “himself” in all his meme-ified glory.
content: Thirty-two years ago, Nicolas Cage swaggered onto the set of a British talk show to promote his movie “Wild at Heart.” After performing a handspring and several kung fu-style moves, he whipped off his T-shirt, thrust it at the startled host, and put his leather jacket back on over his naked chest before proceeding with the interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kaminer
title: House Hunting in Peru: A Modern Mountain Perch Above Lima
description: Political upheaval has stunted the high-end market in Peru’s capital, but domestic buyers are keeping demand high at the middle and lower end of the market.
content: A stone mountain rises behind this geometric 12,055-square-foot house in La Planicie, an affluent neighborhood in the eastern La Molina district of Lima, Peru. Designed by Peruvian firm Domenack Arquitectos and built in 2014, the seven-bedroom, eight-bath house incorporates natural elements like an indoor waterfall and volcanic stone around the pool deck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Some Like It Hot’ Musical Plans Fall Opening on Broadway
description: Christian Borle, J. Harrison Ghee and Adrianna Hicks will star in a stage adaptation of the 1959 film comedy about two musicians on the run.
content: A new musical adaptation of “Some Like It Hot,” a classic cross-dressing comedy that is being recalibrated for contemporary audiences, will start performances in November and open in December on Broadway, the show’s producers said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Will Alaskans Welcome Sarah Palin’s Political Comeback?
description: Charles Homans, a New York Times reporter who lived in Alaska during Palin’s ascent, reflects on the state’s astonishing political transformation.
content: Greetings from your host Blake Hounshell. Leah Askarinam is off today. We’re joined tonight by our colleague Charles Homans, who writes about Sarah Palin and Alaska’s changing politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Virus cases are rising in New York, but Hochul says it’s hard to predict what form the ‘bump’ might take.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul warned that the state could be seeing the beginning of another spike in coronavirus cases, this one driven by two new versions of the Omicron variant.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York warned on Wednesday that another spike in coronavirus cases could be underway in the state, this one driven by two new versions of the Omicron variant. Even so, Ms. Hochul said, it was difficult to forecast what form the current “bump” might take, urging “common sense” safety measures such as home testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Mist a Spot
description: Joseph Greenbaum gives puzzles a good name.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle comes to us from Joseph Greenbaum, who is making his fourth appearance in the New York Times Crossword since his debut less than a year ago, in August 2021. But this is Mr. Greenbaum’s first puzzle with a 9A!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Nancy Wartik
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: I Lived the #VanLife. It Wasn’t Pretty.
description: The writer Caity Weaver’s pursuit of the manifest destiny of the millennial generation ended up looking better in the photos.
content: For the most part, I don’t remember things. My memory is not so much vague as it is glitchy; a generally blank screen that sometimes blinks to life and performs basic recall tasks. With scarce exceptions, my recollections are so inaccessible to me that they are more like the memories of a person I have never met or spoken to. Once, while rewatching one of my favorite films, I found myself wondering what its lead actor might be like in real life. Several scenes later, a revelation jolted me: I once flew cross-country to have lunch with that man, interviewed him about his life for two hours and had my 1,400-word summary of the experience published in a magazine. Geotagged iPhone photos are often some of my only clues that I have been somewhere or done something; I cherish them as proof that I, at one point, left my house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon, Zanele Mji and Lynsey Chutel
title: Housing Crisis Propels High Death Toll in South Africa Floods
description: The catastrophe underscored an overlooked reality in the fight against extreme weather: Protecting people is as much about tackling social issues as environmental ones.
content: DURBAN, South Africa — In 2009, as officials in the port city of Durban prepared to host the next year’s World Cup of soccer, they moved hundreds of residents from their tin shacks near the city center to a flood-prone field south of town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘I Deserve to Be Here’: Riding His First Professional Gig to Broadway
description: Jaquel Spivey graduated from college last May. Now he’s making his Broadway debut as the star of Michael R. Jackson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning musical, “A Strange Loop.”
content: During his first-ever Broadway curtain call, a teary Jaquel Spivey was overcome with emotion as he and his castmates received a standing ovation. There had been times when the young star of “A Strange Loop” wasn’t sure he had what it took to play the demanding part. But there he was on the evening of April 14, finally taking his first Broadway bow after a tryout run in Washington, months of rehearsals and a series of Covid-related delays that postponed the start of preview performances by a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: New York Times Names Marc Lacey and Carolyn Ryan as Managing Editors
description: A pair of veteran Times journalists will serve in the newsroom’s No. 2 position under the new executive editor, Joe Kahn.
content: Joseph F. Kahn, newly appointed as the next executive editor of The New York Times, announced his leadership team on Wednesday in a memo that urged his colleagues “to produce the most ambitious, consequential and creative work of our careers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: The Antiquarian Book Fair: From Sondheim’s Letters to a Brontë Discovery
description: Among the rarities on view at the New York International Antiquarian Book Fair are also a 1555 treatise on tennis and Amy Winehouse’s personal library.
content: The New York International Antiquarian Book Fair, which returns to the Park Avenue Armory this weekend after a two-year pandemic hiatus, is one of the world’s leading gatherings of the rare book tribe. For more casual visitors, it can also be an experience of dizzying information overload.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Cecilia Kang
title: Barack Obama Takes On a New Role: Fighting Disinformation
description: The former president has embarked on a campaign to warn that the scourge of online falsehoods has eroded the foundations of democracy.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2011, President Barack Obama swept into Silicon Valley and yukked it up with Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s founder. The occasion was a town hall with the social network’s employees that covered the burning issues of the day: taxes, health care, the promise of technology to solve the nation’s problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: Parisian Love Stories for the Age of Talk Less, Message More
description: Jacques Audiard made his new film “Paris, 13th District” as a counterpoint to the New Wave movies that shaped his early ideas of love and intimacy.
content: Midway through “Paris, 13th District,” the new film directed by Jacques Audiard, Émilie sneaks away from her job waitressing in a Chinese restaurant to hook up with a man she’s found on a dating app. When she returns from the encounter, she is so filled with happiness that she dances through the aisles as the customers applaud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Calls to Give Heavy Weapons to Ukraine Divide Germany’s Government
description: Weeks after Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a paradigm shift in military strategy, his government is struggling to balance domestic politics, how to help Ukraine and anxiety over provoking Russia. that
content: BERLIN — Fierce debate over sending heavy weapons to Ukraine has struck a fault line through Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government, raising questions about his leadership and dampening expectations of his ability to help steer Europe through the continent’s most dramatic security crisis since World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Lincoln Center Plans a Return to Full-Scale Summer Programming
description: A festival, Summer for the City, which includes elements of Mostly Mozart, is part of an effort to attract younger, more diverse audiences.
content: After more than two years of upheaval brought on by the coronavirus pandemic, Lincoln Center will stage a festival this summer aimed at helping New York City heal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Nikola Jokic’s Passing Is Just Plain Fun to Watch
description: Jokic, the Denver Nuggets center, may be one of the best passers ever. But Golden State is making it more difficult for him to do what he does best.
content: DENVER — About midway through the third quarter of a game in early April, Nikola Jokic was pushing the ball up the court after grabbing a defensive rebound for the Denver Nuggets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen walked out of a G20 meeting as Russia’s finance minister spoke.
description: Several central bank governors and finance ministers protested Russia’s participation at the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank.
content: Several finance ministers and central bankers including Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen and Ukraine’s finance minister, Serhiy Marchenko, abruptly left a Group of 20 meeting in protest on Wednesday when Russia’s finance minister, Anton Siluanov, started to speak, according to a person familiar with the meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Herschel Walker’s Senate Bid in Georgia Is Powered by Fandom
description: The football-star-turned-candidate has been converting Bulldogs fans into supporters. But some Republicans worry voters are blinded by his celebrity.
content: LaGRANGE, Ga. — Most came dressed in University of Georgia jerseys, hats and T-shirts. Some carried footballs and framed posters. It was a campaign stop for a Senate candidate, but for many Georgians who came to see Herschel Walker, politics was hardly the only draw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: Solving a Garden-Party Murder in 1920s India
description: Harini Nagendra’s new novel, “The Bangalore Detectives Club,” stars a bookish, Sherlock-Holmes-loving young bride.
content: The first in an effervescent new mystery series by the ecology professor Harini Nagendra, THE BANGALORE DETECTIVES CLUB (Pegasus Crime, 304 pp., $26.95) turns the clock back a century. Kaveri has moved to Bangalore to become a proper wife to Ramu, the doctor to whom she was given in marriage as a 16-year-old. A solitary and bookish woman with a penchant for mathematics is not quite what her mother-in-law had in mind, and she makes that known. “Too much studying is bad for women,” she warns. “It makes their brains go soft.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: How the Worst Site Can Become the Best Garden
description: James Golden’s New Jersey garden, Federal Twist, taught him that a gardener must match the plants to the place — however difficult that seems.
content: “A real wasteland.” “A derelict wood.” And: “Sort of frightening.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
title: Alex Jones Reaches Out to Justice Dept. About Jan. 6 Interview
description: The effort by the Trump ally to get an immunity deal is the latest sign of progress in the investigation, which recently brought on a well-regarded prosecutor.
content: The federal investigation into efforts to overturn the 2020 election appears to be gaining traction, with the Justice Department having brought in a well-regarded new prosecutor to help run the inquiry and a high-profile witness seeking a deal to provide information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Russia rejects calls for a cease-fire to enable evacuations, saying Ukraine only wants time to arm.
description: Civilians, including children, remain trapped in the eastern Ukraine region of Donbas and in the devastated port city of Mariupol.
content: Russia rejected calls for a cease-fire to allow for civilian evacuations in Ukraine on Tuesday, saying that requests to pause the fighting were not sincere and would only provide time to arm Ukrainian fighters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Tennessee G.O.P. Removes Trump-Backed House Candidate From Ballot
description: Morgan Ortagus, a former State Department spokeswoman who moved to Tennessee last year, was taken off the ballot, along with two others.
content: The Tennessee Republican Party voted on Tuesday to drop Morgan Ortagus, whose bid for a House seat was endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, from the primary ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: High Winds Are Expected to Drive Fast-Moving Wildfire in Arizona
description: The Tunnel fire, near Flagstaff, swelled to more than 16,000 acres and prompted the evacuation of more than 700 homes, the authorities said.
content: Breezy and dry conditions were expected across Northern Arizona on Wednesday, hampering efforts to contain a fast-growing wildfire that prompted the evacuation of more than 700 homes the day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: From Amazon to Starbucks, America Is Unionizing. Will Politics Catch Up?
description: A debate on how unions build power today and whether politicians — particularly Democrats — are still behind them.
content: From Amazon and Starbucks to large media companies, unionization has become a siren call for workers — white- and blue-collar — fighting for rights and fair wages. But in 2022, after two years of a pandemic, how have our ideas about unions changed? And are Democrats, the so-called party of the unions, still allies in the fight for workers’ rights?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: A Problem for Macron in France’s Election: ‘The Hatred He Arouses’
description: Given the choice between a president they suspect of despising ordinary people and a far-right candidate they detest, many French voters may stay home.
content: LE HAVRE, France — As an ardent supporter of President Emmanuel Macron of France, Nicole Liot was all smiles after seeing him at a recent campaign stop. But she was also worried about the final round of the French election this Sunday. In her lifetime, she had never seen such intense dislike for a president among some French.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Why a Chinese Security Deal in the Pacific Could Ripple Through the World
description: In potentially opening the door to a Chinese military base, the Solomon Islands threatens the balance of power in a vital shipping region.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — When the Solomon Islands’ prime minister stood before Parliament on Wednesday to announce that his government had signed a sweeping security agreement with China, he insisted that it would “not adversely impact or undermine the peace and harmony of our region.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: How America’s Farmers Got Cut Out of the Supply Chain
description: As shipping companies concentrate on the most lucrative routes from China to California, almond growers are struggling to transport their wares.
content: During a normal spring, the sight of orchards bursting with clusters of almonds is a boon throughout California’s Central Valley. Here is money growing on trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and Kellen Browning
title: Apple Store workers in Atlanta are the first to formally seek a union.
description: The petition for a union vote continues a trend of organizing at service-sector employers like Starbucks and Amazon.
content: Employees at an Apple store in Atlanta filed a petition on Wednesday to hold a union election. If successful, the workers could form the first union at an Apple retail store in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: This Novel Recounts a Haunted Sibling Relationship in Epic Verse
description: Patrick McCabe’s “Poguemahone” is set mostly in hippie-era London, when an Irish brother and sister struggle against society and their own worst natures.
content: The Irish novelist Patrick McCabe is, in modern parlance, a lot. His narrators are often less unreliable than anti-reliable, their thinking expressed in purposely haphazard prose. His books are stuffed with violence and jokes, mental illness and cultural references, folklore and history, often written with Joycean vigor and obfuscation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: We Politicized Masks. Now What?
description: It’s time to get behind high-impact, low-backlash Covid policies.
content: April 20, 2022: This article has been updated to include information about the Department of Justice’s filing notice to appeal to reinstate the transportation mask mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Feeling the Squeeze? How to Be a Thrifty Traveler as Prices Soar
description: Inflation is here and it’s wreaking havoc on travel budgets. Our Frugal Traveler columnist on how to strategize in a world of rising prices.
content: Travelers are feeling the squeeze. Rising prices related to inflation, employment shortages and supply chain slowdowns are hitting the travel industry, just as summer travel planning — compounded by pent-up demand — peaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang, Joy Dong and Amy Chang Chien
title: Shanghai’s Low Covid Death Toll Revives Questions About China’s Numbers
description: The country’s largest city has recorded just 17 Covid deaths, despite surging cases. How China defines a Covid death may be part of the reason.
content: By the numbers, Shanghai has been an exemplar of how to save lives during a pandemic. Despite the city’s more than 400,000 Covid-19 infections, just 17 people have died, according to officials, statistics they have touted as proof that their strategy of strict lockdowns and mass quarantines works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Bitcoin Mining Is a Tax on Our Electrical Grid
description: The willpower to reduce Bitcoin’s carbon footprint is muted amid wild cryptocurrency speculation.
content: The people behind Bitcoin, the No. 1 cryptocurrency by market value (and renown), are under heavy pressure to reduce its carbon footprint — the planet-warming emissions from burning fossil fuels for electricity to run the network’s computations, known as mining. I spoke with people on both sides of the argument and came away thinking that Bitcoin is highly unlikely to change its fundamental way of operating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: More Pandemic Fallout: The Chronically Absent Student
description: At one middle school, more than 40 percent of the students have been chronically absent this year. Districts are going to great lengths — offering gift cards, night classes — to reach them.
content: After the coronavirus pandemic pushed his classes online in the spring of 2020, Isaac Mosley, now 18, got used to spending his time outside of school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: ‘Artists Are Migrants’: A Nigerian-Irish Dancer’s Multiplicities
description: The Lagos-born, Ireland-raised dancer Mufutau Yusuf comes to the Irish Arts Center with “Owe,” a solo, he says, “about my ancestry, my Yoruba heritage.”
content: When the dancer Mufutau Yusuf says “I will always consider myself a migrant,” he means it in several senses. One is biographical. Born in Lagos, Nigeria, he moved to Ireland when he was 9. As a young adult, he studied dance in Austria for four years. Now 29, he lives and works mostly in Belgium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: How Loneliness Is Damaging Our Health
description: Even before the pandemic, there was an “epidemic of loneliness,” and it was affecting physical health and life expectancy.
content: For two years you didn’t see friends like you used to. You missed your colleagues from work, even the barista on the way there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Colin Moynihan
title: Johnny Depp, Accused of Spousal Abuse, Says Ex-Wife Was the Aggressor
description: The actor testified in a defamation case that he filed against his ex-wife, Amber Heard, who has said he often struck her during their relationship.
content: The actor Johnny Depp took the stand for the second day on Wednesday to describe his turbulent marriage to the actress Amber Heard, whom he has sued for defamation, accusing her of “demeaning name-calling” that often escalated into physical violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: ASAP Rocky Arrested in Connection With Los Angeles Shooting
description: The rapper, 33, was detained in connection with a November 2021 incident upon returning from Barbados with his pregnant girlfriend, Rihanna.
content: The New York rapper ASAP Rocky was arrested on Wednesday in Los Angeles on a charge of assault with a deadly weapon stemming from an alleged nonfatal shooting last year, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Florida Senate Passes Congressional Map Giving G.O.P. a Big Edge
description: The map, proposed by Gov. Ron DeSantis, would most likely add four Republican districts while eliminating three held by Democrats.
content: Florida Republicans are poised to adopt one of the nation’s most aggressive congressional maps, pressing forward with a proposal from Gov. Ron DeSantis that would most likely add four congressional districts for the party while eliminating three held by Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $850,000 Homes in Virginia, Louisiana and Colorado
description: A 1938 cottage in Richmond, a 13-acre retreat in Abita Springs and a Craftsman bungalow in Denver.
content: About a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Washington, Richmond is filled with bustling, family-friendly neighborhoods like this one, just a few blocks from the University of Richmond, a private liberal arts college with about 3,900 students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Isn’t Shocked the New Mask Ruling Came From Florida
description: “You can’t let Florida make health decisions for the entire country!” Colbert said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Checking Out: Trump Hotel Sale Will End an Era
description: The $375 million sale of a Washington hotel that served as an influence and access bazaar for lawmakers, administration officials and other Trump allies is slated to be finalized this month.
content: WASHINGTON — It’s last call at the bar of the Trump International Hotel in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Fashioning ‘The First Lady’
description: The new Showtime series on Michelle Obama, Betty Ford and Eleanor Roosevelt makes the connection between substance and style.
content: It is a coincidence, but a telling one, that the day after “The First Lady,” the series that is a revisionist take on presidential wives as seen through the intertwined stories of Michelle Obama, Betty Ford and Eleanor Roosevelt, premiered on Showtime, Dr. Jill Biden hosted the White House Easter egg roll. Or rather, the Easter “Eggucation” roll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘The Bad Guys’ Review: Smirking All the Way to the Bank
description: In a heist film-inspired DreamWorks comedy, the Big Bad Wolf goes good, begrudgingly.
content: There’s an old joke among animation lovers that the difference between Pixar and DreamWorks is a matter of conceptual vision: While Pixar movies tend to be wildly original feats of creativity and imagination, DreamWorks movies are usually about anthropomorphic animals doing fairly standard human stuff while smirking. There’s even a popular term for the wry, self-satisfied expression their characters invariably wear: DreamWorks Face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: Netflix shares plunge 35 percent after announcing subscriber losses.
description: The streaming company said 200,000 subscribers left its platform in the first quarter.
content: Netflix shares tumbled 35 percent Wednesday after the company announced a loss of 200,000 subscribers in the first quarter of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj
title: People should keep wearing masks in public even if they are not required, regional W.H.O. officials say.
description: Masks have been proven to be highly effective at reducing coronavirus transmission when used properly, according to the W.H.O.
content: Regional officials at the World Health Organization on Wednesday encouraged everyone to continue to wear face masks in public to reduce coronavirus transmission, even if local authorities no longer mandate their use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Mitch Smith
title: With Joy and Fear, Americans Watch Sweeping Mask Rules Vanish
description: Many travelers removed their masks after a judge struck down a federal mandate for public transit. Health experts voiced concern, but President Biden said it was now up to individuals.
content: It began in midair. Shortly after a federal judge struck down mask requirements on planes, pilots got on intercoms to share the news, and some passengers tore off their masks with whoops and glee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aatish Bhatia
title: F.D.A. Warns Patients About Some Prenatal Genetic Tests
description: The agency cites concerns that some manufacturers’ claims about test performance “may not be supported with sound scientific evidence.”
content: The Food and Drug Administration warned expectant parents on Tuesday about the risk of false positive results from a booming line of prenatal blood tests that screen fetuses for rare genetic conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Study Raises Questions About Popular Genetic Test for ‘Abnormal’ Embryos
description: The test leads people undergoing in vitro fertilization to discard thousands of embryos each year. The new research found implanting some “abnormal” embryos resulted in healthy live births.
content: When they began their first two rounds of in vitro fertilization in 2015, Anna Dahlquist and her husband, Brian, took a common genetic test to determine the condition of the embryos they had created. The results were devastating: All 13 were “abnormal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Man Charged With Hate Crimes After Violent Attacks on Four Jews
description: The episode, which included a carjacking, took place in and around Lakewood, N.J., which has a significant Orthodox Jewish community.
content: Federal law enforcement charged a New Jersey man with hate crimes on Wednesday for a violent attack on four Jewish men, in which two were hit by a vehicle that had been carjacked from the first victim. The incident took place in and around Lakewood, N.J., which is home to one of the largest Orthodox Jewish communities in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Blackman and S. B. Tillman
title: Only the Feds Could Disqualify Madison Cawthorn and Marjorie Taylor Greene
description: State courts or election boards lack jurisdiction in keeping alleged insurrectionists off a congressional ballot.
content: The events of Jan. 6, 2021, are casting a long shadow over the midterm elections. Voters in North Carolina are seeking to bar Representative Madison Cawthorn from running for re-election to his House seat, and those in Georgia are trying to do the same to Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivien Schweitzer
title: Nicholas Angelich, Ocean-Straddling Pianist, Dies at 51
description: American-born and Paris-based since he was 13, he performed on both sides of the Atlantic, winning acclaim specializing in Germanic repertory.
content: Nicholas Angelich, an American-born pianist best known for his soulful interpretations of the Germanic repertory, which he performed with elegant virtuosity and expressive intimacy, died on Monday in Paris, where he had lived since he was 13. He was 51.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: He Was a Penniless Donor to the Far Right. He Was Also a Russian Spy.
description: An investigation in Slovakia has exposed how Russian clandestine operations are trying to sow discord in Europe and create sympathy for Moscow over Ukraine.
content: KOSICE, Slovakia — He lived with his sick mother and never had a regular job. He had no obvious source of income and, according to his uncle, even signed up for welfare benefits as a caregiver deserving of state support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Boxing Distances Itself From a Figure Sought by the U.S. Government
description: Promoters and boxers are disavowing Daniel Kinahan, who the Treasury Department said is the leader of a murderous drug cartel.
content: One week after the United States government levied sanctions on Daniel Kinahan, the reputed head of an Irish drug cartel, recriminations are mounting for the world of boxing, with many fighters, promoters and managers racing to distance themselves from Kinahan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Inside Vs. Outside
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Biden Is Expected to Tap Arizona Prosecutor as Interim Director of A.T.F.
description: The selection of Gary M. Restaino is intended to inject a sense of urgency into the bureau until President Biden’s nominee to oversee the agency permanently is confirmed.
content: The Biden administration plans to pick Gary M. Restaino, the top U.S. prosecutor in Arizona, as the interim director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives until a permanent leader is confirmed, according to officials with knowledge of the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Warning Ukraine’s Friends to ‘Think Twice,’ Putin Tests Advanced Missile
description: Vladimir Putin said Russia’s test-firing of its new I.C.B.M. sends a message, as his forces prepare for a broad offensive in eastern Ukraine.
content: With a pointed warning to Ukraine’s Western allies, Russia test-launched a new intercontinental missile on Wednesday, even as it unleashed a hail of bombs, artillery and missiles inside Ukraine in a drive to weaken Ukrainian defenses for a major ground offensive in the east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why New York’s a Lonely Town, Especially Since Covid
description: We are still learning what the effects of prolonged isolation could be in a city where a million people live alone.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at something we all experienced in the pandemic when we lost friends or simply couldn’t get together — loneliness. We’ll also look at how the New York Public Library and the Brooklyn Public Library are countering book-banning efforts in other parts of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
title: Deep in Colombia, Rebels and Soldiers Fight for the Same Prize: Drugs
description: The country signed a historic peace deal more than five years ago. But a power vacuum is fueling the rise of new armed groups competing to control the drug trade.
content: PUTUMAYO, Colombia — In a rebel-held town deep in the jungle, Joel ran drills beside his comrades, line after line of them in camouflage and boots, rifles at their sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rim-Sarah Alouane
title: Marine Le Pen Looks Like the Mainstream Because the Mainstream Looks Like Her
description: As a French Muslim citizen, I fear for my country.
content: TOULOUSE, France — In 2017, we thought we’d seen the worst French politics could offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Russia’s Missile Test Fuels U.S. Fears of an Isolated Putin
description: American and foreign leaders have been weighing whether their success in making Russia a diplomatic pariah could push President Vladimir V. Putin to strike in new ways.
content: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin’s calculated move on Wednesday to test-launch a new intercontinental ballistic missile, declaring it a warning to those in the West who “try to threaten our country,” fed into a growing concern inside the Biden administration: that Russia is now so isolated from the rest of the world that Mr. Putin sees little downside to provocative actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: How Diverse Is Your Community?
description: Do you see people from different walks of life interacting with each other, or does your town or city feel divided?
content: Is your town or city made up of people from different walks of life? Do you often see and interact with people of different races, nationalities, religions and abilities? Do you hear a variety of languages? Do you know people who have different kinds of family structures?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Let’s Eat Grandma’s Electro Pop Is Glittery. Its Subjects Are Weighty.
description: Jenny Hollingworth and Rosa Walton’s band has always been rooted in their deep friendship. Then the tides changed.
content: Let’s Eat Grandma spent part of the fall of 2019 in a series of seaside Airbnbs on the coast of Norwich, England. The town was so small it was impossible to find a store that sold bath towels, so the duo endured one five-day stretch sharing the same tea towel they used to dry the dishes. It was here that Rosa Walton played her bandmate and best friend Jenny Hollingworth the song that could have ended their group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Court Brings Assange One Step Closer to Extradition
description: The court formally ordered the extradition of the WikiLeaks founder to the United States, but it still needs approval from a British cabinet minister and his defense can appeal to her directly.
content: LONDON — A London court on Wednesday ordered the extradition of the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange to the United States, the latest but not the last step in a long-running battle in British courtrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Chelsea Daniel, Rachel Quester, Eric Krupke, Rob Szypko, Patricia Willens, Jessica Cheung, Lisa Tobin, Lisa Chow, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: When Texas Went After Transgender Care, Part 1
description: The story of one family seeking gender-affirming care in the midst of a political storm.
content: In recent years, there has been a sharp increase in the number of younger Americans who identify as transgender and are seeking medical intervention to support their transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: With or Without Trump, the MAGA Movement Is the Future of the Republican Party
description: The losing candidate in the 2020 election continues to exert tremendous power over his party. What does this portend for its future?
content: The fissures in the Democratic Party are on display for all to see, since it is the party in power, but the divisions in the Republican Party and the conservative movement are deeper, wider and far more threatening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Threatens Escalation
description: Plus the emergence of armed militias in Colombia and questions over China’s Covid death toll.
content: As Russia continued its offensive in the Donbas region of Ukraine by raining artillery across the 300-mile eastern front, it took the provocative step of test launching an intercontinental ballistic missile designed to evade defenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Ukrainians Face Delays and Roadblocks as They Try to Enter California
description: A growing number of refugees are hoping to cross from Tijuana into San Diego.
content: As the war in Ukraine stretches on longer than many anticipated, California’s southern border has increasingly become a destination for refugees from the war-torn country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘How I Learned to Drive’ Review: Many Miles to Go Before a Reckoning
description: Mary-Louise Parker and David Morse have returned to Paula Vogel’s 1997 Pulitzer-winning play about sexual abuse for its Broadway debut.
content: It’s rare to encounter the kind of breathless silence I experienced during an unnerving hotel room scene in the unforgettable revival of Paula Vogel’s “How I Learned to Drive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
title: Mystery Persists After Initial Report Into China Eastern Jet Crash
description: A preliminary report by China’s air safety regulator summarized what worked during the flight, but did not speculate on what caused the plane to nose-dive.
content: BEIJING — The pilots had met China’s standards for flying a commercial jet. No problems were found with the aircraft before it took off. No dangerous cargo had been loaded aboard. Communications with the plane appeared normal until its deadly plunge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: Diego Maradona: Soccer’s Brilliant, Tortured Bad Boy
description: A new biography by a Spanish journalist who had access to members of Maradona’s inner circle.
content: MARADONAThe Boy. The Rebel. The God.By Guillem Balagué
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Campaign Ordered to Pay $1.3 Million to Omarosa Manigault Newman in NDA case
description: An arbitrator found Mr. Trump’s campaign owes the former White House aide and “Apprentice” star for legal fees, after he sued her for writing a tell-all book.
content: A court arbitrator has ordered former President Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign to pay nearly $1.3 million in legal fees to Omarosa Manigault Newman, the former “Apprentice” star, White House aide and author of the first tell-all book about the Trump White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Here’s What Changes When New York Raises Its Covid Risk Level
description: The city will reach a yellow, or medium, risk level if new cases surpass 200 a week for every 100,000 residents. Here’s what that would mean.
content: As coronavirus cases rise again, fueled by BA.2, the highly contagious Omicron subvariant, New York City is on the cusp of moving to a yellow, or medium, risk level from a green or low risk level. But what does that mean for the city’s residents and what precautions should they take? And what restrictions might the city enact in response to the increased threat?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Why Everyone Wants to Buy Twitter
description: Elon Musk is the latest person who thinks he can fulfill Twitter’s untapped potential.
content: Elon Musk is the latest rich guy to have fallen for the trap of Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix’s Stumble Could Be a Warning Sign for Streaming Industry
description: The company faces a number of challenges, but its problems may be an indication that its competitors are racing toward an unstable future.
content: Many entertainment executives, tired of playing catch-up to a Silicon Valley interloper, have been waiting for the comeuppance of Netflix. But this may not have been the way they hoped it would happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: On the Front Line in the East
description: Ukrainians in the Donbas are facing new perils from war.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Michael Levenson
title: Intruder Is Killed at Peruvian Ambassador’s Washington Home
description: Secret Service officers fatally shot an intruder after a confrontation at the residence, officials said.
content: Secret Service officers fatally shot an intruder on Wednesday morning at a mansion in Northwest Washington that has long served as the Peruvian ambassador’s residence, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: ‘Rust’ Producers Get Maximum Fine in Cinematographer’s Death
description: The production company, which included the actor Alec Baldwin, was fined $136,000 and was criticized for showing indifference to “recognized hazards.”
content: New Mexico state regulators faulted producers of the movie “Rust” in a report Wednesday that said the film management’s indifference to dangers involved in handling guns on set had led to the death of the cinematographer Halyna Hutchins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: In the fog of dementia, one grandmother learns again and again that her country is at war.
description: Millions of Ukrainians have been displaced since the war started. Many elderly or disabled people have been unable or unwilling to leave their homes.
content: Every morning, Olga Boichak’s grandmother wakes up at her home in western Ukraine, turns on the television and discovers anew that her country is at war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: When Should You Mask?
description: Tips for how to make tough choices, regardless of policy changes.
content: On Monday, Philadelphia reinstated its mask mandate as cases there rose. (New York City may soon follow.) Hours later, a federal judge struck down the federal mask mandate for planes and public transit.
source.name: The New York Times

description: There is an estimated multibillion-dollar market in Japan for food you can't eat. The craftsmanship can be extraordinary.

description: President Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen, the French far-right leader, are facing off tonight in a critical debate ahead of Sunday's runoff vote.

description: The Chemex is great at making coffee but not so great at keeping it hot.

title: How Inflation Has Shrunk Your Dollar
description: U.S. inflation rose to 8.5% in March, reaching a four-decade high. So how are rising prices affecting you?
content: U.S. inflation rose to 8.5% in March, reaching a four-decade high. So how are rising prices affecting you?

title: What You Get for $850,000
description: A 1938 cottage in Richmond, Va.; a 13-acre retreat in Abita Springs, La.; and a Craftsman bungalow in Denver.
content: A 1938 cottage in Richmond, Va.; a 13-acre retreat in Abita Springs, La.; and a Craftsman bungalow in Denver.

title: Living In ... West Orange, N.J.
description: During the pandemic, the Essex County township has attracted city buyers with its open space and relatively affordable housing — all less than 20 miles from Midtown.
content: During the pandemic, the Essex County township has attracted city buyers with its open space and relatively affordable housing — all less than 20 miles from Midtown.

title: How a Lush Garden Grew Out of Soil Like ‘Wet Plastic’
description: James Golden’s New Jersey garden, Federal Twist, taught him that a gardener must match the plants to the place — however difficult that seems.

title: Carved Into the Mountains of Lima
description: This modern seven-bedroom house carved into in the hills of Lima, Peru, is on the market for $2 million.
content: This modern seven-bedroom house carved into in the hills of Lima, Peru, is on the market for $2 million.

author: By Brent McDonald
title: What Mariupol’s Steel Fortress Looked Like 3 Months Ago
description: On Jan. 20, The New York Times captured drone video over the sprawling Azovstal Steel and Iron works complex in Mariupol, Ukraine. Now, it is a battered fortress for the last Ukrainian defenders and their families battling Russian forces.
content: On Jan. 20, The New York Times captured drone video over the sprawling Azovstal Steel and Iron works complex in Mariupol, Ukraine. Now, it is a battered fortress for the last Ukrainian defenders and their families battling Russian forces.

description: I’m a critic-at-large on the Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
content: I’m a critic-at-large on the Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

title: Corrections: April 20, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 20, 2022.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about retracted or challenged studies linked to Cassava Sciences’ Alzheimer’s drug misstated Dr. David Bredt’s employment status. He is no longer with MPM Capital.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Prosecuting a Nurse for a Medical Error
description: Reader urge measures to reduce stress and exhaustion and argue that mistakes should not be criminalized. Also: Drone operators; globalization.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: That neglected sourdough starter? Yes, you can revive it.
content: Good morning. That sourdough starter in the back of the fridge that you haven’t used since the heady days early in the pandemic, when all you could do was bake more sourdough bread? It’s fine! It might have some gross, dark liquid on top of it, yes. They call that “hooch.” Just pour it off and get some fresh flour and water into the container. Within a day or so you’ll be back in business and ready to set up morning waffles or English muffins (above), an evening pizza, or lunchtime sourdough no-knead bread.
source.name: The New York Times
